ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about folktale and fairy tale scholarship, and my eyes were opened to new dimensions about this genre that I never knew existed.
I have become a better writer and learned a lot about folktales.

I really improved my writing skills and knowledge of folktale and fairy tale scholarship as a whole. Professor Kaliambou was very well-versed in her subjects and a super great mentor in the writing process of my papers.

I learned a lot about folktales, their themes, their transmission, and the transmission of media more broadly. I think I improved by writing as well. I gained a new appreciation for folktales and fairy tales as a genre.
I learned about the intricacies that make up the history of fairy tales and folk tales, as well as the nuances that can be found when comparing the effects that different cultures have had on them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel that it was a bit too Eurocentric at times and almost wished we could have focused more on folktales from other areas, such as Africa, Latin America, Asia, etc. It would have enriched the canon that we were exposed to that mainly focused on Greek, Hungarian, Russian, Italian, and French stories.

Strengths: The topic is really interesting, and Professor Kaliambou is very knowledgeable about it and enthusiastic about it. She is also very supportive when students are interested in certain topics and is responsive to emails. The reading load is reasonable as well. Weaknesses: I didn't like the group-aspect of the presentation assignment. Professor Kaliambou can be intimidating at times.
The content of the course was informative and engaging, however style of teaching left much to be desired.
I think this is a very strong course with engaging material. The professor gives good feedback on student writing.

I think this course could be improved by making it more seminar/discussion based. I feel like there was a lot of review of knowledge, but it wasn't overall that much covered. It was a bit of a weird mix of seminar/lecture. I really enjoyed when we as a class would talk about things and just let the conversation go.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, very interesting, learned a lot
Yes!! Especially if you have any interest in reading about fairy tales or just taking a course that feels enjoyable while informative, Fairytales and Folktales is for you!!
Very likely yes. It is an interesting topic, the readings are fun to do, and the workload is not atrocious.
While the content of the course was very fun and interesting, the professor is not someone I would recommend.
I would recommend this course to another student but only if they're very very interested in the subject matter, because I often felt as though this class was rather demanding and time consuming.

extras.title: E&RS 617 01/LITR 328 01/MGRK 212 01 - Folktales and Fairy Tales TR
